--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Joseph Reisinger <joeraii@...> wrote:
> 
> - "=
Implicit" determination, as per GRNs which specify networks  
> through if-=
then clauses, works on the level of the interfaces, 
and  
> new objects be=
nefit from being "compatible" with the interfaces  
> already. That is, a n=
ew object that arises through a mutation is  
> immediately connected up to=
 other objects at many different levels 
in  
> the hierarchy because its c=
onnecting via a predefined interface. 
This  
> is achieved implicitly, wit=
hout the need for a bunch of mutations  
> connecting up each node explicit=
ly.
> 

Sounds like it could be good or bad.  On the one hand, it makes the=
 
relationships among multiple objects immediately accessible to 
evolution=
.  On the other hand, it means that as soon as an object is 
introduced it =
is hooked up to a litany of random dependencies.  
Because of the combinato=
rial complexity of multiple interdepencies, 
I would guess that such a sudd=
en ballooning of relationships could 
hamstring evolution just as much as i=
t could help it.  

It's a bit related the theory behind starting simply in=
 NEAT:  While 
it may turn out that you need a lot of structure to do what =
you 
want, you don't necessarily want to start out with all that 
structure=
 at the get-go because none of it is justified by a single 
fitness evaluat=
ion.  The same may be true, perhaps, with implicit 
connectivity.

> To me =
it seems like this approach has merit, although it is 
obviously  
> a litt=
le counter-intuitive: Why should we sacrifice fine-grained  
> control for =
this weird idea of "implicit similarity" based on  
> interfaces? But actua=
lly it turns out to be quite powerful, at 
least  
> for complex domains li=
ke othello.
> 

If I understand correctly what you've done it is to show th=
at your 
indirect encoding, which does in part leverage this kind of implic=
it 
connectivity, outperforms regular NEAT in Othello.  

From that, I'm no=
t sure if you can zero in on a particular aspect of 
the indirect encoding =
and say that it is this aspect that is 
critical to the power of indirect e=
ncoding in general.  Even if you 
could prove that one particular property =
of a specific encoding 
helped it outperform NEAT, that does not imply that=
 a completely 
different alternative encoding could not do just as well or =
better 
while leaving out entirely the particular feature you found to be 
=
important.  

Like you said, to get past intuitions what's really needed is=
 just 
comparisons among different indirect encodings.

> The next step I t=
hink is to compare these approaches side by side  
> across a bunch of doma=
ins to see where they differ. I think there 
is  
> a lot of room here to d=
evelop a robust theory of representation  
> design in evolutionary search.=

> 
> I should point out that actually carrying out all the comparisons 
an=
d  
> theorizing necessary here is probably going to constitute the bulk 
o=
f  
> my PhD dissertation, so watch this space for future developments.
> 
=
> > These are obviously subtle issues that merit more research, 
since I
> =
> am speaking only from intuition.  It's a really interesting 
topic.
> > W=
e can talk about this more in Hawaii in a couple days :)
> 
> Definitely, I=
'm looking forward to it.
> 
> 

That's great, sounds like it will be great=
 dissertation!
